title: 114_hr5910
content: The Act titled "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury to report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Treasury establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence. The Group reports directly to the Secretary of the Treasury and includes the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes as chairperson. The Treasury establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence. The Group is chaired by the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes and includes senior representatives from various offices and bureaus of the Department of the Treasury. The Treasury establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence, chaired by the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes. The Group includes senior representatives from various offices and bureaus of the Department of the Treasury, such as the Office of International Affairs, Economic Policy, Legislative Affairs, Foreign Assets Control, Intelligence and Analysis, Terrorist Financing, and the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. The Group conducts contingency planning for the Office of Foreign Assets Control. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence conducts contingency planning for the Office of Foreign Assets Control to impose economic sanctions rapidly under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act or other laws. The Office of Terrorism and Financial Intelligence's Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group conducts contingency planning for the Office of Foreign Assets Control to impose economic sanctions quickly under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act or other laws, considering the vulnerability of the target country or entity. The contingency planning required for imposing economic sanctions is guided by considerations such as the vulnerability of the target country or entity, the effectiveness of different types of sanctions, and the feasibility of imposing sanctions. The effectiveness of economic sanctions depends on factors such as the target country's vulnerability, the type of sanctions used, and the feasibility of imposing them. Considerations include the impact on the US economy, whether unilateral or multilateral sanctions are more effective, and the costs involved. The Group will review economic sanctions programs to improve US economic sanctions policy, considering factors like the target country's vulnerability, type of sanctions, costs to the US economy, effectiveness of unilateral vs. multilateral sanctions, and the process for lifting sanctions. The Group will review economic sanctions programs to identify specific and general problems with US economic sanctions policy, including the manner in which sanctions will be lifted. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes will review economic sanctions programs to identify specific and general problems with US economic sanctions policy and create a strategy for improvement. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes will review and improve economic sanctions programs, coordinating with various government departments to develop US economic sanctions policy. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes coordinates the development of US economic sanctions policy with various government departments and ensures equal information sharing among them. The Group, designated by the President, ensures equal information sharing on US economic sanctions policy among government departments. The term 'executive agency' is defined as in section 105 of title 5, United States Code.
